awd_titl_txt: Preserving and Enhancing Access to the Survey of Zapotec and Chatino Languages
awd_abstract_narration: Zapotec-Chatino is a diverse language family with a 2500-year history involving the earliest writing and State-level social organization in the Western Hemisphere. Currently several Zapotec-Chatino languages have gone extinct only within the last generation and more than half of this family will be lost in the next generation. The work of the Documenting Endangered Languages (DEL) project "Preserving and Enhancing Access to the Survey of Zapotec and Chatino Languages" supported by the National Science Foundation will ensure that the extensive media and transcription files of the Zapotec and Chatino Survey are permanently preserved, providing free online dissemination that makes them discoverable and accessible for scholarly and educational purposes. Between 2007 and 2010, the Survey documented the languages spoken in 104 towns of Oaxaca, Mexico. In response to the decline of cultural knowledge through loss of these languages, young Zapotec and Chatino speakers applied a linguistic survey and transcribed the results. Without the work of this DEL project, that documentation will remain beyond access for scholars and community members. This project creates a permanent archive of the numerous Zapotec-Chatino varieties, compiling the largest born-digital dataset of a Native American language family. The Zapotec and Chatino Survey corpus includes over 300,000 recorded and transcribed utterances containing thousands of vocabulary items and hundreds of grammatical patterns. The corpus is applicable to researching multiple levels of linguistic structure with potential for comparative linguistic study, through which we can gain insights into human cognition and into languages and cultures of ancient America. The project will contribute to the professionalization of a young scholar by hosting a postdoctoral position and involve undergraduate students in research. The project will produce materials that can be used for language maintenance efforts in Zapotec-Chatino communities and can be applied in classrooms in the U.S. to broaden American understandings language endangerment.

por.por_cntn:
This project, which ran from 09/01/2013 - 08/31/2016, ensured that the extensive media and transcription file results of the Zapotec and Chatino Language Survey (2007-2010), were archived with metadata to provide free online dissemination and ensure that these results would be discoverable and accessible for scholarly, educational, and language revitalization purposes in perpetuity.  

The Intellectual Merit of this project included the preservation of the Zapotec and Chatino Survey corpus which includes over 317,500 recorded and transcribed utterances containing thousands of vocabulary items and grammatical patterns. The more than one million-word corpus is applicable to researching multiple levels of linguistic structure including phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and intonation phrases, and for comparative linguistics, through which we gain insights into human cognition, and into the prehistory of languages and cultures of ancient America. As described below, these intellectual merits are being realized in current research by students and faculty at multiple universities as ongoing outcomes of this NSF Award.

The Broader Impacts of this work included facilitating the collaboration of linguists and anthropologists from several U.S. and International institutions. The project had community involvement including Zapotec and Chatino speaking graduate students, who have used its materials to work on advanced degrees in linguistics. The data from the project have directly contributed to Master’s and Doctoral theses. The project also contributed to the training and professional development of a Zapotecan languages focused postdoctoral researcher, who went on to earn a permanent position at a public university. The project has helped train several graduate students, and involved several undergraduate students in scholarly research, providing experience which strengthened their employment and graduate school applications. Some of these students have even gone on to pursue graduate study in linguistics. Beyond these impacts, the project has had positive education benefits raising awareness of Indigenous language loss in America (as roughly 60% of the towns surveyed had no children learning the Indigenous language) and providing an archive of materials for heritage language education.

The extensive effort to make the survey results available online involved work by the research team to assess, enhance, and standardize the formats of the original audio recordings; verify entries in background interviews and the Indigenous language speaker’s responses to survey questions; conduct additional fieldwork to fill gaps we discovered; generate metadata for each file including information such as dates of recording, content of recording, participants, languages, file names, and associated files; and create the nested tree structure of the archives to group related files together in hierarchies. Audio and transcription files were directly uploaded and linked in the archives, or delivered to archive curators for onsite ingestion. We developed web-based programming for querying the archive, and tested access and tool use. Through this NSF funded project the language survey results have been archived in "The Language Archive" of the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics, and INALI, the National Institute of Indigenous Languages of Mexico, with an additional copy of the archive sent to AILLA (the Archive of the Indigenous Languages of Latin America) for ingestion by their staff at the University of Texas, Austin.

During the last period of this award 09/01/2015 - 08/31/2016 we were able to develop a set of online tools designed to facilitate research on the archived data of the Zapotec and Chatino survey to develop an etymological database (an online dictionary with information related to the historical development of words from the ancestor language to the roughly 30 descendant languages). Researchers are using these online tools to search the archive and display results for any selected grouping of languages, regions, or branches of the family, and to annotate and code these results for analysis. 

In this last year of the project the survey was utilized as data in PhD dissertation projects at multiple U.S. Universities (including linguistics research at Georgetown University and at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington DC, SUNY Buffalo, University of California Santa Barbara, UC Berkeley; in Archaeology and Linguistic research at University of Indiana involving graduate and undergraduate students; the training undergraduate students at the University of Virginia; and internationally for linguistics PhD research at Oxford University in England, and the National Autonomous University of Mexico. The principal investigator is using the search tools and archive as data for a forthcoming book that relates the history of Western Zapotecan to the origin of state-level society in the western hemisphere.

In sum: this NSF funded project has ensured that the largest collection of linguistic documentation to date of the Native American language family of Zapotec-Chatino will be preserved and accessible in perpetuity to continue to be used as data for scientific discovery and as a resource available to speaker and heritage communities.
